Consider a reaction-diffusion equation given by:

$\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = D_1 \nabla^2 u + R(u,v)$,

$\frac{\partial v}{\partial t} = D_2 \nabla^2 v + S(u,v)$,

where $u$ and $v$ represent the concentration of two chemical substances, $D_1$ and $D_2$ are the diffusion coefficients, and $R(u,v)$ and $S(u,v)$ represent the reaction terms.

Suppose we have a 2D square domain with sides of length 1 unit, and the initial concentrations of $u$ and $v$ are given by:

$u(x,y,0) = \begin{cases} 1, & \text{if }0.4 \leq x,y \leq 0.6 \\ 0, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$

$v(x,y,0) = \begin{cases} 1, & \text{if }0.2 \leq x,y \leq 0.8 \\ 0, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$

We want to find the concentration of $u$ and $v$ at time $t=0.5$ units, given that $D_1=0.1, D_2=0.2, R(u,v)=0.1u-v, S(u,v)=-0.2u+0.15v$. Use a numerical method, such as the finite difference method or the method of lines, to solve the equations.

To solve this problem numerically, we will use the finite difference method. First, we discretize the spatial domain using a grid with spacing $\Delta x$ and $\Delta y$. We will also discretize the time domain using a time step $\Delta t$. Let $u_{i,j}^n$ and $v_{i,j}^n$ represent the concentrations of $u$ and $v$ at grid point $(i\Delta x, j\Delta y)$ and time $n\Delta t$. We can approximate the spatial derivatives using central differences:

$\nabla^2 u \approx \frac{u_{i+1,j}^n - 2u_{i,j}^n + u_{i-1,j}^n}{\Delta x^2} + \frac{u_{i,j+1}^n - 2u_{i,j}^n + u_{i,j-1}^n}{\Delta y^2}$

$\nabla^2 v \approx \frac{v_{i+1,j}^n - 2v_{i,j}^n + v_{i-1,j}^n}{\Delta x^2} + \frac{v_{i,j+1}^n - 2v_{i,j}^n + v_{i,j-1}^n}{\Delta y^2}$

We can approximate the time derivatives using forward differences:

$\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} \approx \frac{u_{i,j}^{n+1} - u_{i,j}^n}{\Delta t}$

$\frac{\partial v}{\partial t} \approx \frac{v_{i,j}^{n+1} - v_{i,j}^n}{\Delta t}$

Substituting these approximations into the reaction-diffusion equations, we get:

$\frac{u_{i,j}^{n+1} - u_{i,j}^n}{\Delta t} = D_1 \left(\frac{u_{i+1,j}^n - 2u_{i,j}^n + u_{i-1,j}^n}{\Delta x^2} + \frac{u_{i,j+1}^n - 2u_{i,j}^n + u_{i,j-1}^n}{\Delta y^2}\right) + R(u_{i,j}^n, v_{i,j}^n)$

$\frac{v_{i,j}^{n+1} - v_{i,j}^n}{\Delta t} = D_2 \left(\frac{v_{i+1,j}^n - 2v_{i,j}^n + v_{i-1,j}^n}{\Delta x^2} + \frac{v_{i,j+1}^n - 2v_{i,j}^n + v_{i,j-1}^n}{\Delta y^2}\right) + S(u_{i,j}^n, v_{i,j}^n)$

We can rearrange these equations to solve for the concentrations at the next time step:

$u_{i,j}^{n+1} = u_{i,j}^n + \Delta t \left[D_1 \left(\frac{u_{i+1,j}^n - 2u_{i,j}^n + u_{i-1,j}^n}{\Delta x^2} + \frac{u_{i,j+1}^n - 2u_{i,j}^n + u_{i,j-1}^n}{\Delta y^2}\right) + R(u_{i,j}^n, v_{i,j}^n)\right]$

$v_{i,j}^{n+1} = v_{i,j}^n + \Delta t \left[D_2 \left(\frac{v_{i+1,j}^n - 2v_{i,j}^n + v_{i-1,j}^n}{\Delta x^2} + \frac{v_{i,j+1}^n - 2v_{i,j}^n + v_{i,j-1}^n}{\Delta y^2}\right) + S(u_{i,j}^n, v_{i,j}^n)\right]$

Now we can implement this finite difference method in a numerical algorithm. We will initialize the concentrations according to the given initial conditions, and then update the concentrations at each time step using the above equations. We will continue updating the concentrations until we reach the desired time $t=0.5$ units. Note that the choice of $\Delta x$, $\Delta y$, and $\Delta t$ will affect the accuracy and stability of the numerical solution.
